R Class for graphs

Karen Cristine Goncalves

2019-10-12

Sintax

  • Functions: word()
    • Get help - help("word") or ?word
  • Variable = this or Variable \<\- this
  • Comparisons:
    • x \> y - is x greater than y? (x and y are numbers or )
    • x \>= y - is x greater or equal to y? (x and y are numbers or )
    • x \< y - is x less than y?
    • x \<= y - is x less or equal y?
    • x == y - is x equal to y? (Note that you need to use 2 “=” signs)
    • x != y - is x different from y?
      • The exclamation point negates the comparison, so it is similar to ! x == y

Sintax - Run the commands below

variable = 1 Variable

variable2 <- 2 variable2

1 == 2 1 == variable

1 > 2 1 <= 2

variable2 != 1

Data types

  • Character - anything between quotes (single ’, or double “), also called string

  • Numeric - numbers, with or withou decimals

  • Logical - TRUE or T and FALSE or F

  • Factor - categories

  • How to know? Ask: class(variable)

Data types - Run the commands below

variable = 1 variable2 = “I am a character” variable3 = F variable4 = factor(“class”)

class(variable) class(variable2) class(variable3) class(variable4)

Data types - Conversion

  • From numeric
    • To factor - as.factor(1)
    • To character - as.character(1)
    • To logical - as.logical(1)
  • From categorical/factor
    • To numeric - as.numeric(factor(“class”))
      • Returns the number of the category
    • To character - as.character(factor(“class”))
  • From logical
    • To factor - not possible, returns NA (not available)
    • To character - as.character(FALSE)
    • To numeric - as.logical(FALSE)

Collections of data

  • Vector - values of a single type separated by “,” inside c()
    • c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5)
    • It’s class will be the type of data inside
  • Matrix - vector of 2 dimensions
    • matrix(c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6), nrow=2, ncol=3)
  • Data frame - a table, with several vectors of the same size, each as a column
    • data.frame(c(1, 2), c(3, 4), c(5, 6))
  • List - a mix of anything
    • list(c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5), matrix(c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6), nrow=2, ncol=3), data.frame(c(1, 2), c(3, 4), c(5, 6)), F)

Collections of data - Run the commands below

variable = c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6) class(variable)

variable2 = matrix(c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6), nrow=2, ncol=3) class(variable2)

variable3 = data.frame(c(1, 2), c(3, 4), c(5, 6)) class(variable3)

list(variable, variable2, variable3, F, 1)

Your PC

  • Find where you are - get working directory (folder)
    • getwd()
  • Change folders - set working directory
    • setwd("myFolder")
  • See the contents of the folder
    • list.files()

Load files

  • Save tables in excel in format:
    • csv - comma separated values or semi-colon separated values
    • txt or tsv - tab separated values
  • Load the data with the function read.csv or read.delim, adding:
    • Name of the file, with location if not in the current folder
    • Optionals:
      • header=F or header=T - first line has the names of the columns or not?
      • sep="\t" for tab separated columns
      • row.names=1 - which column has the name of the rows
      • skip=2 - how many rows to disconsider (here, 2)

file_csv = read.csv(“myFile.csv”) # optional - header=F, row.names=2, sep=“;” file_txt = read.delim(“myFile.txt”) # optional - header=F, row.names=2, sep=” ”
